   Assessment and Plan
   88M with afib on coumadin, CHF(EF 25-30%), s/p PPM, pancreatic
   insufficiency, admitted with GIB and reported orthostatic hypotension
   .
   #. GI Bleed - In the setting of supratherapeutic INR on home coumadin.
   Had episodes of dark stool concerning for upper GI source or right
   colonic source. Ddx includes gastric/duodenal ulcer (although NG lavage
   negative), diverticula, AVM, mass in the context of supratherapeutic
   INR. Last EGD and colonoscopy in [**2180**] were wnl other than some gastric
   polyps and grade I hemorrhoids. Patient has been HD stable (no
   hypotensive, tachycardic), but his Hct is down from baseline. GI aware
   and plan to do EGD and colonoscopy with prep tomorrow if patient
   remains stable overnight. Patient still due for blood transfusions as
   he is difficult crossmatch. He is s/p FFP and IV vitamin K
   - GI aware, appreciate recs
   - transfuse to keep Hct>25
   - serial Hct and coags - Q6hr
   - f/u coags s/p reversal with FFP and vitamin K
   - hold coumadin
   - type and Cross, crossmatch 2 units
   - IV access: 2 PIVs - 18g
   - NGT placement tonight for golytely prep overnight
   - Tagged RBC scan if active bleeding
   - IV BID PPI
   - Hold antihypertensives
   - Keep NPO for now
   .
   # Cardiac/rhythm: Patient with known afib on coumadin - with
   supratherapeutic INR. s/p DDDR pacemaker in [**2176**]. Currently with HR in
   60s which is at baseline.
   - hold beta blocker while monitoring for GIB
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Cardiac/pump: Last ECHO in [**2177**] showed EF of 25-30%. Patient
   hypovolemic on exam from blood loss with no evidence of overload but as
   plan to transfuse with [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 124**] monitor respiratory status, physical
   exam for volume overload. Patient on home lasix of 40mg PO daily to
   every other day
   - lasix for diuresis prn
   .
   # Cardiac/ischemia: Patient with no chest pain, 1st set of enzymes with
   slightly increased troponin but CK flat. EKG with wide complex QRS with
   RBBB.
   - cycle enzymes
   - repeat EKG in AM, obtain old EKG from PCP
   [**Name Initial (PRE) **] continue simvastatin
   - hold beta blocker for now
   .
   # s/p infected prosthetic knee replacement in right knee: afebrile, LE
   at baseline, no indication of infection
   - continue bactrim ppx
   - continue knee brace
   .
   # Gout
   - continue allopurinol
   .
   # Insomnia: Patient recently seen in sleep lab for nightmares
   - continue seroquel QHS
   - try to maintain sleep-wake cycle
   .
   #. FEN - NPO for now, NGT placement for golytely prep overnight
   .
   #. Access - 2 x 18g PIV
   .
   #. PPx -
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   .
   #. [**Name (NI) **] - Son and daughter at bedside on admission. Has 2 caretakers at
   bedside, home assistant Ms. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 866**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 867**], also home OT therapist.
   Confirmed full code status with son. ICU consent signed.
   .
   #. Code - Full code
   .
   #. Dispo - ICU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now, golytely prep by NGT planned overnight
   Glycemic Control:

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
- The patient is an 88-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation on Coumadin, congestive heart failure, pancreatic insufficiency, and gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).
- He presented with episodes of dark stool, which was concerning for an upper GI source or right colonic source.
- His Hct is down from baseline, indicating ongoing blood loss.
- The patient has been hemodynamically stable but requires blood transfusions due to difficulty with crossmatching.
- He received 1 unit of blood overnight, with an increase in HCT from 19.1 to 21.5, and another unit is hanging this morning.
- A nasogastric tube (NGT) was placed, and the patient underwent golytely prep overnight with black tarry stool at the beginning and clear liquid stool this morning.
- The patient remains NPO for possible esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy this morning.
- He has allergies to penicillins, ciprofloxacin, and cefazolin.
- The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F), heart rate of 62 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 111/49 mmHg to 123/91 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
- The patient

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 88-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure (EF 25-30%), previous pacemaker placement, pancreatic insufficiency, and a prosthetic knee replacement. He was admitted with melena, likely due to a duodenal ulcer. His INR was supratherapeutic, and he received two units of blood transfusion overnight. An endoscopy and colonoscopy were performed, revealing a duodenal ulcer without active bleeding and normal colonic mucosa. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate in the 60s and blood pressure ranging from 111/49 to 123/91 mmHg. He has mild edema in his extremities but no evidence of fluid overload. Lab results show an elevated white blood cell count and slightly increased troponin level, but other cardiac markers are within normal limits. The patient's coagulation profile is abnormal, with a prolonged prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and INR. He is currently on various medications including proton pump inhibitors, allopurinol, and simvastatin. The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and plans include transfusing blood products to maintain a hematocrit (Hct) above 25, holding antihypertensives, and repeating laboratory tests. The patient has a full code status and is expected to be

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). They received two units of packed red blood cells overnight, with an increase in hematocrit from 19.1% to 21.5%. A nasogastric tube (NGT) was placed, and the patient underwent a golytely prep overnight, producing black tarry stool initially but clear liquid stool in the morning. The patient has been kept nil per os (NPO) for possible esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy this morning.

Allergies include penicillins, ciprofloxacin, and adhesive tape, all causing rashes. The patient is currently receiving pantoprazole (Protonix) and other ICU medications.

Review of systems remains unchanged from admission except for the ongoing GIB. Vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 62 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 111/49 to 123/91 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. The patient's rhythm is set to atrioventricular paced.

Fluid balance shows an input of 1,603 mL and output of 600 mL through urine and 850 mL through NG drainage. Total fluid input is 4,162 mL, with a total fluid output of 3

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 88-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure (ejection fraction 25-30%), previous pacemaker placement, pancreatic insufficiency, and a prosthetic knee replacement. He was admitted with gastrointestinal bleeding (GI bleed) and found to have a non-bleeding duodenal ulcer. The patient received 5 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) due to significant blood loss. His hemoglobin concentration increased from 21.1% to 28.5%. He is currently receiving pantoprazole (proton pump inhibitor) for stress ulcer prophylaxis and heparin sodium for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.7°C, heart rate of 60 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 102/44 mmHg to 76/37 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. He is currently on mechanical ventilation support with a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg. Fluid balance shows an intake of 6,861 mL and output of 2,450 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 4,411 mL. 

Physical examination reveals fine rales at the lung bases, regular heart rhythm, soft abdomen, and trace bilateral edema. The

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient presented with a gastrointestinal bleed and underwent a colonoscopy and endoscopy, revealing a non-bleeding ulcer in the duodenum. The patient received a total of 5 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs), resulting in a hematocrit (Hct) increase from 21.1% to 28.5%. The patient was restarted on home lasix dosage. The patient has allergies to penicillins, ciprofloxacin, and cefazolin. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 35.7°C, heart rate of 60 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 102/44 mmHg to 123/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's fluid balance shows a net loss of 313 mL over 24 hours. The patient is receiving prophylactic heparin sodium, pantoprazole, fentanyl, and midazolam. The patient's lab results show elevated potassium levels and decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. The patient's white blood cell count is within normal range, and there is a slight increase in creatinine levels. The patient has a history of GI bleed, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient is currently in the ICU receiving respiratory support and is on multiple medications for prophylaxis and treatment.
